blocks.value: St. José Luis Sánchez del Río was born in 1913 in Sahuayo, Michoacán, Mexico, during a time of severe persecution of the Catholic Church. The government had outlawed public worship and was executing priests and lay Catholics who refused to renounce their faith. This conflict, known as the Cristero War, saw many martyrs for the faith.

José was only 13 years old when he joined the Cristeros, Catholic rebels fighting for religious freedom. His mother initially refused to let him join, but José was determined to fight for Christ the King. He served as a flag bearer for the Cristero army.

In February 1928, José was captured by government forces. He was imprisoned and tortured, and his captors tried to force him to renounounce his faith. They cut the soles of his feet and made him walk through the town to the cemetery where he would be executed. With each painful step, José cried out "Viva Cristo Rey!" (Long live Christ the King!). Before he was shot, he drew a cross on the ground, knelt, and forgave his executioners. He was 14 years old. José Luis was beatified by Pope Benedict XVI in 2005 and canonized by Pope Francis in 2016.
